[7] Thus, it seems to be evidence for ureide degradation by allantoate amidohydrolase and ureidoglycolate amidohydrolase, rather than by urea-releasing enzymes, although both pathways could work in parallel. [8] In fact, it has been reported that soybean degrades ureides mainly by the amidohydrolase pathway producing ammonium, although with a small portion of ureide degradation through urea . [1] Allantoate- or ureidoglycolate-degrading activities have been determined in just a few cases in plants (; ; ; ) and green algae . [2] Allantoicase from the alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii is the only allantoate-degrading activity purified from a photosynthetic organism . [3] Only one ureidoglycolate-degrading enzyme has been partially purified, from common bean developing pods , and this enzyme has been reported to be a ureidoglycolate amidohydrolase.
